byline.contributor: Omar al-Jawoshy reported from Baghdad and Tim Arango from Istanbul. Falih Hassan and Ahmed Salah contributed reporting.
byline.original: By OMAR AL-JAWOSHY and TIM ARANGO

abstract: Iraqi Prime Min Haider al-Abadi is responding to widespread antigovernment protests by pledging to drastically reform country's dysfunctional political system; proposals include new corruption inquiry and elimination of sectarian and party quotas in appointment of top officials.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Abadi’s proposals could be a turning point in the dysfunctional politics of Iraq that have persisted since the American invasion in 2003.

headline.main: Premier Haider al-Abadi, Facing Protests, Proposes Iraqi Government Overhaul
headline.print_headline: Facing Protests, Iraqi Premier Proposes Government Reforms

snippet: Mr. Abadi’s proposals could be a turning point in the dysfunctional politics of Iraq that have persisted since the American invasion in 2003.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
